Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I glance at the clock, my hands deep in soapy water as I scrub the last of the dishes. My husband calls from the living room, asking if I’ve finished dusting the guest room. Relatives are arriving soon, and the house must be spotless—he’s counting on me to help make everything perfect. I nod, but my mind is elsewhere. The polling station closes in two hours, and I still haven’t voted. I promised myself I wouldn’t miss this election, not after all the debates and discussions at the dinner table. But the laundry still needs folding, and the bathroom isn’t ready. My husband’s voice is gentle but firm, reminding me how important it is to make a good impression on his family. I feel the weight of his expectations, the pride he takes in our home. At the same time, I feel the tug of my civic duty, the responsibility to have my voice heard. My heart pounds as I weigh the demands, torn between being the supportive wife and the responsible voter, knowing I can’t fully satisfy both.
